title: Hasan Abdal
text:
Hasan Abdal (<a href="Punjabi%20language">Punjabi</a>, ), is a city in <a href="Attock%20District">Attock District</a> of <a href="Punjab%20%28Pakistan%29">Punjab Province</a> in <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, located 40 km northwest of the country's capital city, <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>. Hassan Abdal is the headquarter of Hasan Abdal <a href="Tehsil">Tehsil</a> (sub-district).
As home of the <a href="Gurdwara%20Panja%20Sahib">Gurdwara Panja Sahib</a>, one of the most sacred sites in <a href="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>, Hasan Abdal is an important pilgrimage destination. The city is also notable for its association with the 16th century <a href="Mughal%20Emperor">Mughal Emperor</a> <a href="Akbar">Akbar</a> - several monuments in the town date to the Akbar period, including the <a href="Mughal%20Garden%20Wah">Mughal Gardens of Wah</a>, <a href="Hakimon%20ka%20Maqbara">Hakimon ka Maqbara</a>, and <a href="Tomb%20of%20Lala%20Rukh">Tomb of Lala Rukh</a>. Hasan Abdal is also near the city of <a href="Taxila">Taxila</a> – a <a href="UNESCO%20World%20Heritage%20Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> famous for its ancient era <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a> and <a href="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> ruins.
Location.
Hasan Abdal is located in a strategic part of northern <a href="Punjab">Punjab</a>, and was the location from which Mughal war expeditions were sent to the northwestern frontier. In modern times, Hasan Abdal lies at the intersection of the <a href="Karakoram%20Highway">Karakoram Highway</a>, and the <a href="M1%20motorway%20%28Pakistan%29">M1 Motorway</a>. As part of the multibillion-dollar <a href="China-Pakistan%20Economic%20Corridor">China-Pakistan Economic Corridor</a> (CPEC), the Hasan Abdal area will serve as the terminus for CPEC's <a href="Western%20Alignment">Western Alignment</a>, while the <a href="Hakla%E2%80%93Dera%20Ismail%20Khan%20Motorway">Hakla–Dera Ismail Khan Motorway</a> will commence at Hasan Abdal.
History.
The famous Chinese traveler <a href="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> who visited the place in the 7th century A.D. mentions the sacred spring of Elapatra about 70 <a href="Li%20%28unit%29">li</a> to the northwest of <a href="Taxila%20%28modern%29">Taxila</a> which has been identified as the spring at of <a href="Gurdwara%20Panja%20Sahib">Gurdwara Panja Sahib</a>.
The town is mentioned in <a href="Ain-i-Akbari">Ain-i-Akbari</a> in the context that Shams al-Din built himself a <a href="Vault%20%28architecture%29">vault</a> there in which lies Hakim Abu’l Fath buried. <a href="Akbar">Akbar</a>’s visit to the town on his way back from <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> is also mentioned.
William Finch who travelled through India between 1608 and 1611 describes Hasan Abdal to be a "pleasant town with a small river and many fair tanks in which are many fishes with golden rings in their noses ...; the water so clear that you may see a penny in the bottom".
The town was seat for Mughal warring expeditions to the northwest frontier. The Mughal emperor <a href="Jehangir">Jehangir</a> mentions in his <a href="Tuzk-e-Jahangiri">Tuzk-e-Jahangiri</a> this town by the name of Baba Hasan Abdal where he stayed for three days. He also praises the city in these words: "The celebrated place at this station is a spring which flows from the foot of a little hill, exceedingly clear, sweet and nice...". Hasan Abdal was visited by various Mughal kings on their way to <a href="Kashmir%20region">Kashmir</a>
<a href="Raja%20Man%20Singh">Raja Man Singh</a> built the nearby <a href="Mughal%20Garden%20Wah">Wah Gardens</a> during the reign of <a href="Akbar">Akbar</a>. The terraced gardens were divided into four parts. <a href="Shah%20Jahan">Shah Jahan</a> rested at Hasan Abdal's Wah Gardens on his four expeditions to <a href="Kabul">Kabul</a>. Emperor <a href="Aurangzeb">Aurangzeb</a> stayed at the for over a year beginning in 1674, in order to quell the "<a href="Afridi">Afridi</a> Revolt". The presence of Emperor Aurangzeb at the gardens convinced many local <a href="Pashtun%20tribes">Pashtun tribes</a> to abandon the rebellion, and join forces with the Mughals.
Muslim Tradition.
"The Muslim version of the story is that one Hasan, a <a href="Gujjar">Gujjar</a>, had many buffaloes; that a Faqir named Abdal came and asked him for a draught of milk. Hasan said, I would gladly give you some, but my buffaloes are at present dry. Abdal laid his hand on one of them and said, "Now milk it." He did so, and soon gave him a copious draught. Abdal expressed his gratitude to Hasan, and asked what he could do for him. Hasan replied that they were much straitened for want of water, on which Abdal struck the neighbouring hills in two places, from which the two streams of Hasan Abdal have come forth. On the departure of the Faqir, Hasan said the spot should hereafter be called after them jointly".
Gurdwara.
In 1521 the founder of the Sikh faith, <a href="Guru%20Nanak">Guru Nanak</a>, arrived in Hasan Abdal, a Gurdwara was built on the spot that he stayed containing a sacred rock that is believed to contain the hand print of Guru Nanak. Punja or panja ( ; ਪੰਜਾ ) :hand or paw. There are different traditions about the origin of the Hand print.
Infrastructure.
Hasan Abdal is located near the intersection of the <a href="Karakoram%20Highway">Karakoram Highway</a> heading northwest, and the <a href="M1%20motorway%20%28Pakistan%29">M1 Motorway</a> that connects Hassan Abdal to points northwest and southeast. As part of the multibillion-dollar <a href="China%E2%80%93Pakistan%20Economic%20Corridor">China–Pakistan Economic Corridor</a> (CPEC), the Karakoram Highway will be rebuilt, while the Hasan Abdal area will serve as the terminus for CPEC's <a href="Western%20Alignment">Western Alignment</a>. From the nearby village of Hakla, the <a href="Hakla%E2%80%93Dera%20Ismail%20Khan%20Motorway">Hakla–Dera Ismail Khan Motorway</a> will run southwest out of the city and link Hassan Abdal to <a href="Dera%20Ismail%20Khan">Dera Ismail Khan</a> in <a href="Khyber%20Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber Pakhtunkhwa</a> province.
Health and medical care.
There is a Tehsil Headquarters Hospital and numerous privately owned clinics in and around the city. Despite the exponential growth in population, the health care facilities are extremely insufficient. Many hospitals are located nearby <a href="Wah%20Cantonment">Wah Cantonment</a> or in <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>.
Education.
The city has several state owned primary schools, a high school each for boys and girls, a higher secondary school each for boys and girls and a degree college for women. There are a number of privately run schools to make up for the shortfall of the state owned ones. These include Trends School, and Presentation Convent High School, the latter of which was established in 1956.
Cadet College, Hasan Abdal.
<a href="Cadet%20College%20Hasan%20Abdal">Cadet College Hasan Abdal</a> is the first <a href="Cadet%20Colleges%20in%20Pakistan">Cadet College</a> in <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and was established by the government of <a href="Punjab%20%28Pakistan%29">Punjab</a> at the initiative of General <a href="Muhammad%20Ayub%20Khan">Muhammad Ayub Khan</a>, the then <a href="Commander-in-Chief">Commander-in-Chief</a> of the <a href="Pakistan%20Army">Pakistan Army</a>, originally to serve as a feeder institution to the Services Academies. For this purpose, Military Wings were started in 1952 in <a href="Government%20Post%20Graduate%20College%20Sahiwal">Government College</a>, <a href="Sahiwal">Sahiwal</a>, and <a href="Islamia%20College%20%28Peshawar%29">Islamia College</a>, <a href="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>. On the completion of buildings at the present location, the Military Wings were shifted to Hasan Abdal and the Cadet College started functioning as Punjab Cadet College in April 1954. In 1960, the government constituted a Board of Governors to exercise administrative control over the college. 
<a href="Hugh%20Catchpole">Hugh Catchpole</a> (1907-1997) was the founder Principal of the College. According to his will he was buried at Cadet College Hasan Abdal. He served at Cadet College Hasan Abdal for 4 years then he joined <a href="PAF%20Public%20School%20Sargodha">PAF Public School Sargodha</a> as founder principal.
The college is located on the <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>/<a href="Peshawar">Peshawar</a> road about 29 miles (48 km) from <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>/<a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>, in natural surroundings near the junction of the National Highway and <a href="Grand%20Trunk%20Road">Grand Trunk Road</a>.
Environment.
Surrounded by the fresh water springs with crystal clear water and <a href="Loquat">Loquat</a> orchards the city used to be an idyllic place till recent past. Its beauty as mentioned in the earliest accounts has somehow survived the ill planning that has resulted in an exponential increase in its population.
